header.title: Derbyshire shopkeeper will keep selling Golliwogs because ‘they aren’t racist’
header.postText: A shopkeeper in Derbyshire has refused to stop selling Golliwogs because ‘there is nothing racist about them’.', 'Matlock Bath General Store in Matlock Bath has come under criticism for selling the dolls, which are now widely regarded as racist caricatures.', 'Many stores such as Hamleys in London no longer stock the toys, while even their own creator described them as ‘a horrid sight, the blackest gnome’.', 'But the manager of the general store in Matlock, who did not give his name to Metro.co.uk, blasted critics of the dolls and was adamant that he was doing ‘nothing wrong.’', 'Defending his decision to sell them he said: ‘There is nothing racist about them. They are very popular.', '‘I sell them to all minorities. I’m doing nothing wrong.’', 'He argued there was nothing wrong in what he was doing because he gets he gets the Golliwogs from suppliers ‘all over the shop, from all over the country’.', 'But one source, who did not want to be named, was shocked to see a number of the different dolls on sale, saying it was like the shop was ‘caught in a time warp’.', 'The 30-year-old, from London, told Metro.co.uk: ‘It was a general store and had a shelf of golliwogs of different sizes for sale, which was quite a shock to see.’', '‘It isn’t something you expect to see in this day and age.’', 'Golliwogs – black-skinned dolls with exaggerated red lips and frizzy hair designed to look like minstrels – are based on a character created by Florence Kate Upton in the 19th century.', 'Upton’s character was, in turn, based on a blackface minstrel – a white person who painted their face black, had exaggerated frizzy hair, and wore bright pink lipstick in a racist caricature of black people.', 'Earlier this year Andy Wilkinson, owner of shop the Upstairs Downstairs in Kent vowed to continue selling them despite complaints from neighbours who called his store ‘an embarrassment to the town.’', 'While in February senior Labour councillor Lynn Sterry came under fire for supporting a campaign to ‘Bring Back the Golliwog,’ arguing the offensive dolls reminded her of a childhood toy.
header.socioLingVar: Ethnicity - General,Ethnicity - Black, Ideological and Political Identity - General,Ethnicity - Native-American,Age - Over 65s,Age - Youngsters,Physical Identity - Physical (and Mental) Impairments

The golliwog was created during a racist era. He was drawn as a caricature of a minstrel -- which itself represented a demeaning image of blacks. There is racial stereotyping of black people in Florence Upton's (creator) books, including The Adventures of Two Dutch Dolls -- such as th e black minstrel playing a banjo on page 45. It appears that the Golliwog was another expression of Upton's racial insensitivity. Certainly later Golliwogs often reflected negative beliefs about blacks -- thieves, miscreants, incompetents. There is little doubt that the words associated with Golliwog -- Golly, Golli, Wog, and Golliwog, itself -- are often used as racial slurs, thus, they a re racist.

Assuming the same rationale, it doesn’t mean that they’re not racist just because you say they’re not. Also, how am I a snowflake for pointing out some historical facts? How dare I oppose your views!! 🙄

Paul Atwork There was a film with the Waylan Bothers a few years ago and they played two white female FBI agents and they whited up.  No one batted an eyelid at that.  Dress up as Michael Jackson (if you're white) and all hell breaks lose.

commentThread.commentText: They were originally made by soldiers in WW1. Called Gulliwags. Because the wool in those days was like a dark worsted (Undyed) it made their faces look darker. I loved my Golliwog! It pains me that people think they are ‘racist’

replies.commentText: Actually they were around before that https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golliwog they were in a book in 1895 but the soldiers did make them for the reason you said
